survival_orientation.purpose: Defines how an individual's nervous system anticipates and responds to perceived threat. Determines baseline safety strategies, reactive patterns, and adaptive survival logic.

axes.description: Orients toward perceived danger, instability, or betrayal. Hypervigilance as default state.
Orients toward managing uncertainty, autonomy, and outcomes. Seeks predictability through control.
Orients toward relational security and belonging. Avoids social rejection, prioritizes connection.
Orients toward competence, performance, and success. Avoids inadequacy or perceived failure.

sub_motives.description: Fear of emotional or physical abandonment; drives clinging, reassurance-seeking, or compliance.
Expectation of deception or hidden agendas; drives distrust, testing behaviors, and vigilance.
Defense of personal control; reacts strongly to constraint, manipulation, or coercion.
Fear of inadequacy; survival linked to performance or perceived capability.
Need for predictability, routine, and structure; threat arises from disruption or chaos.
Assumes the world is unstable or dangerous; prepares for sudden negative shifts.

behavioral_indicators.description: Scanning environment for threat, reading microexpressions, expecting danger.
Conflict avoidance through appeasement or over-accommodation.
Rigid planning and contingency stacking to avoid uncertainty.
Sabotaging opportunities to maintain familiar patterns or avoid failure exposure.
Withdrawal, emotional numbing, or evasion of high-stakes situations.

predictive_signals.description: Likelihood of escalation or shutdown under stress, shaped by perceived threat type.
Longposure-term relational stability patterns across stress, rupture, and repair cycles.
Susceptibility to coercion, flattery, or pressure depending on core survival motive.
Expected coping behaviors in crises; determines meltdown, freeze, or hyperfunction patterns.

reward_strategy.purpose: Defines what an individual pursues to feel fulfilled, successful, secure, or alive. Governs goal selection, desire patterns, ambition type, and the internal reward landscape.

axes.description: Seeks influence, control, and the ability to shape outcomes. Feels rewarded when exerting strength or dominance.
Seeks admiration, recognition, and respect. Feels rewarded by elevated social standing or reputation.
Seeks deep emotional bonds, closeness, belonging, and acceptance. Feels rewarded by intimacy and relational harmony.
Seeks competence, improvement, and excellence. Feels rewarded by developing skills and achieving technical proficiency.
Seeks autonomy, novelty, choice, and open possibilities. Feels rewarded by independence and exploration.
Seeks predictability, order, and long-term security. Feels rewarded by consistency, structure, and routines.

sub_motives.description: A desire to be seen, valued, acknowledged, or validated publicly or privately.
A need for independence and self-directed action; strong resistance to constraint.
A drive for emotional closeness and mutual connection; prioritizes relationships as a core source of meaning.
A drive for developing ability and competence; internal reward comes from mastery, not external praise.
A comfort in predictable structure; avoids disruptive novelty and seeks familiar patterns.
A hunger for novelty, risk, stimulation, and open horizons.

behavioral_indicators.description: Frequently steps into leadership, influence, or decision-making roles.
Uses appearance, communication, or achievements to signal status or identity.
Seeks reassurance, praise, or positive social mirroring.
Becomes intensely focused on tasks related to self-improvement or mastery.
Avoids constraints and seeks novelty, adventure, or unstructured environments.
Maintains routines or predictable patterns to feel grounded.

predictive_signals.description: Predicts long-term vocational direction, ambition type, and workplace preferences.
Determines what type of values or relationships a person remains loyal to over time.
Forecasts negotiation style, persuasion susceptibility, and conflict leverage points.
Predicts how an individual gains influence or social traction in groups or organizations.

conflict_response_pattern.purpose: Defines how an individual reacts to conflict, pressure, or perceived threat. Governs escalation style, avoidance tendencies, emotional expression, and breakdown patterns.

axes.description: Responds by intensifying pressure—arguing, asserting dominance, or increasing intensity.
Responds by retreating physically, emotionally, or communicatively to reduce discomfort.
Responds through amplified emotional expression—crying, pleading, venting, or overwhelming affect.
Responds by detaching into logic, shutting down emotion, or intellectualizing the situation.
Responds by smoothing tension, apologizing, people-pleasing, or complying to restore harmony.

sub_motives.description: Desire to maintain control or avoid being overpowered; drives escalation or rigid argument patterns.
Fear of getting something wrong or being exposed; drives retreat, shutdown, or avoidance.
Need to regain safety through emotional intensity or vulnerability displays.
Seeks psychological distance by shifting into logic, analysis, or emotional numbness.
Instinct to maintain relational stability through appeasement or de-escalation.

behavioral_indicators.description: Raises volume, intensity, or pressure to assert position or regain control.
Disappears, avoids messages, shuts down communication entirely.
Displays overwhelming emotion—crying, pleading, emotional spiraling.
Becomes distant, monotone, silent, or calculated; emotional detachment.
Over-apologizes or takes responsibility to neutralize the conflict.

predictive_signals.description: Predicts relationship rupture patterns: explosive, avoidant, cold, cyclical, or appeasing.
Forecasts how the individual behaves during arguments—pursuer, withdrawer, rescuer, or aggressor.
Identifies tendencies under extreme stress—shutdown, fight, meltdown, or hypercontrol.
Predicts how someone behaves with authority, teammates, or during professional tension.
